Award.AwardTitle: A Novel Mechanism for Pyrimidine Methylation by a Flavin-dependent Enzyme
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes program is supporting the research of Professor Bruce Palfey of the University of Michigan to study the reaction mechanism of the flavin dependent thymidylate synthase. All life requires thymidylate in order to synthesize DNA. The "classic" thymidylate synthase, studied in high detail for half a century, transfers carbon from methylenetetrahydrofolate to deoxyuridine monophosphate through a series of covalent intermediates. It does this without a prosthetic group. In contrast, flavin-dependent thymidylate synthase, discovered just a decade ago, accomplishes the same net transfer of carbon, but somehow the flavin prosthetic group is critical to the process. The reactions that reduce and oxidize the flavin prosthetic group and transfer carbon from methylenetetrahydrofolate will be examined by several spectroscopic and kinetic methods, in the hope of identifying intermediates and understanding how the protein controls the reactions. The novel possibility will be explored that flavin-dependent thymidylate synthase activates deoxyuridine monophosphate by polarization instead of attack by an enzymic nucleophile.

The Broader Impacts of this project include insight on the mechanistic and evolutionary malleability of chemical routes critical to life. The flavin-dependent thymidylate synthase reaction is just one example of the widespread reactions that methylate the pyrimidines of nucleic acids or their precursors. For the students involved, this project is expected to provide multi-disciplinary training, including molecular biology, protein biochemistry, spectroscopy, kinetics and organic synthesis. The investigator plans to recruit underprivileged high school students into the laboratory via participation in the American Chemical Society's Project SEED.

This project is being co-funded by the Biomolecular Dynamics, Structure and Function Cluster in the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division of the BIO Directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Without DNA synthesis, life would cease. Cells synthesize one building-block of DNA, dTMP, by attaching a carbon to the uracil ring of dUMP. However, the carbon, donated by the cellular carbon-donor CH2THF, requires another proton and two electrons in order to complete the conversion of the uracil ring of dUMP to the thymine ring of dTMP. The overall reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme thymidylate synthase, which is found in all  organisms. A type of thymidylate synthase that requires a tightly-bound flavin (a derivative of vitamin b2) was discovered relatively recently. The flavin-dependent thymidylate synthases do not resemble thymidylate synthases that do not require flavins, yet they accomplish the same task of converting dUMP to dTMP using CH2THF as the carbon-donor. The goal of this project was to uncover in detail the chemical steps of this complex conversion, and also to characterize other properties of this unusual enzyme class.

 

The tightly-bound flavin of the enzyme absorbs light, and substrate-binding or chemical reactions at the active site of the enzyme change the absorbance, allowing events at the active site to be observed in real time. Enzyme pre-loaded with electrons and either dUMP or CH2THF is stable. However, mixing with the second substrate so that both dUMP and CH2THF are bound cause a sequence of reactions that are complete in a few seconds. In that time, absorbance spectroscopy detected two reactions. Additionally, mixing reaction-mixtures with concentrated acid destroyed  the enzyme, halting the chemistry of the reaction sequence and allowing the detection of the disappearance of dUMP and formation of dTMP. These types of experiments led to a working model for the formation of dTMP from dUMP.

 

Protein side-chains that were important for the reaction were identified by constructing mutant enzymes. Two Arg residues that interact with the uracil of dUMP proved to be very important. NMR spectroscopy was used to probe changes in the electronic (and, therefore, chemical) environment of the uracil ring upon binding to the enzyme, showing that the enzyme activates dUMP for reaction with CH2THF by causing the loss of a proton from dUMP. Arg 174 is responsible for this deprotonation reaction. Interestingly, the lack of reactivity of a synthetic analog of dUMP strongly suggested that the phosphate group of dUMP plays a critical role after carbon transfer from CH2THF to dUMP.

 

These and other experiments are uncovering the complexities of an enzyme thought to be used by as many as one-third of bacteria.
